results.title: Wildcats and Pipedreams
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Film & Television, John Richardson and David Greig
results.brief_description: Wildcats and Pipedreams follows the crew of an oil drilling rig in the Timor Sea. It gives a fascinating insight into the lives of people living and working in a remote and difficult environment.

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

In this film, titled ‘Just Roaming’, Ted tells the story of a road trip through Victoria. The Parsons travel through Mount Hotham and Myrtleford, down to Melbourne and then back through Bairnsdale and Paynesville on the south coast.

A feature is the footage of the Gliding Club of Victoria, including female pilots, and historic buildings in Melbourne such as the Shrine of Remembrance and Ormond College at the University of Melbourne. There are beautiful scenes of the Victorian countryside throughout.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘E.J. Parsons Presents’, ‘Just Roaming’
00:00:11:00 a 1950s car leaves the driveway of a brick house and drives down a country road
00:00:35:00 flooded roads and paddocks, uprooted trees in the river
00:01:30:00 a visit to the Hume Dam (formerly known as the Hume Weir) including scenes of Lake Hume
00:02:55:00 man with binoculars, looking out to snow covered mountains
00:03:28:00 two women and a man playing with snowballs
00:04:27:00 a man and woman wade through the snow; woman playfully flashing her underwear to the camera
00:04:50:00 snowy countryside
00:06:33:00 the Hotham Heights Hotel in Mount Hotham, with guests on the balcony looking out over the railings
00:06:51:00 bleached white gum trees and yellow buttercups
00:07:33:00 beautiful views across the mountain ranges
00:08:59:00 a clock tower
00:09:18:00 road sign ‘Myrtleford Please Slow Down’
00:09:27:00 a helicoptor landing in a field, followed by footage of gliders taking off and landing
00:10:27:00 logo ‘Gliding Club of Vict.’ on a wing
00:10:33:00 two young men seated in a glider, smiling and waving at the camera
00:10:59:00 a yellow glider taking off
00:11:19:00 young woman in a glider
00:11:57:00 gardens
00:13:14:00 bridge over the Yarra River, Melbourne, with a church spire in the background
00:13:33:00 the Shrine of Remembrance, Melbourne
00:14:18:00 boys in a red row boat on the Yarra
00:14:25:00 Ormond College, University of Melbourne
00:14:38:00 flowers
00:16:11:00 feeding the seagulls at the beach
00:17:16:00 farm paddocks
00:17:28:00 scenic shot of three people on a rocky outcrop
00:17:43:00 sign for ‘Bairnsdale Please Slow Down’ followed by scenes in the country town
00:18:22:00 a unicycle mounted on a white brick wall
00:18:29:00 the Technical School, Bairnsdale
00:20:34:00 road sign ‘Paynesville Please Slow Down’
00:20:55:00 two women walking along the beach
00:21:32:00 view from a boat on the river
00:22:52:00 boat named ‘Krunulla’
00:24:05:00 poplar and pine trees
00:27:09:00 title card ‘Springtime’ followed by scenery in country and footage of farm animals

results.title: [The funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey]
results.brief_description:
This film contains documentary footage of the state funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey, which took place on 30 May, 1951 in Melbourne, Victoria.

The film captures the funeral cortege as it proceeds along Swanston Street, with crowds of people lining the streets and buildings. The flag-covered casket is accompanied by a military band, soldiers and dignitaries. Significant public figures marching in the cortege include Prime Minister Robert Menzies, Governor-General William McKell, Governor of Victoria Sir Dallas Brooks and Chief Justice of the High Court Sir John Latham.

The film includes wonderful footage of Swanston Street from a high vantage point with the Shrine of Remembrance in the distance. There are also great shots of soldiers marching together, military horses, people gathered in front of the Melbourne City Baths and a couple watching on atop the facade of the ‘W.H. Terry Memorial Hall’.

An estimated 300,000 people turned out to watch the funeral procession, which travelled from the Shrine of Remembrance, along St Kilda Road, and up Swanston Street to College Crescent, before proceeding by car to Fawkner Crematorium.

Sir Thomas Blamey (24 Jan 1884 – 27 May 1951) was a General in the Australian army and the only Australian to have achieved the rank of Field Marshal.

results.title: Green Fingers: Looking After Lemons
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Looking After Lemons’, gardener Rod Cantrill shows ways to look after the popular lemon tree.

The narrator points out various issues that can afflict them including collar rot, leaf yellowing, leaf fall, and pests and diseases, while Cantrill works on lemon trees in a beautiful orchard. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Pest and Disease Control
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.
results.description:

description_for_label:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

Green Fingers was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of Green Fingers are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of Sow What, Better Homes and Gardens, and Gardening Australia.

results.title: Beef Carcase Competition
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this film contains footage of dead animals.

This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was made to promote and highlight the pristine quality beef produced in the Western district of Victoria and Eastern South Australia.

It documents the annual contest to select the best beef carcase; in this instance, held in Portland, Victoria.

results.title: Where the River Kiewa Flows
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of the Kiewa Valley diary industry, which supplied milk and butter to the people of Melbourne and Sydney.

The film highlights one farm’s introduction of a piggery to make use of their surplus milk and generate a secondary revenue stream.

results.title: Farm Newsreel No. 1
results.brief_description: This newsreel film features agricultural activities throughout Victoria, Australia. Activities featured include hop harvesting in Myrtleford, tobacco harvesting in Ovens Valley, onion harvesting in Colac, and silage distibution in Upper Pakenham.
results.description: This newsreel film features agricultural activities throughout Victoria, Australia. Activities featured include hop harvesting in Myrtleford, tobacco harvesting in Ovens Valley, onion harvesting in Colac, and silage distibution in Upper Pakenham.

results.title: The Mallee Research Station
results.creator_credit: Colin Webb, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of agricultural scientists working at the Mallee Research Station in Walpeup, Victoria.

The film highlights the research station’s development of wheat production, sheep breeding and pasture improvements. It contains some wonderful examples of farm machinery and farming techniques of the era.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Webb, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
